trans-unit.source: Getting Started with Delivering Video on Demand (VoD) using REST APIs
trans-unit.target: Getting Started with Delivering Video on Demand (VoD) using REST APIs

trans-unit.source: This tutorial walks you through the steps of implementing a Video-on-Demand (VoD) content delivery application with Azure Media Services using REST APIs
trans-unit.target: This tutorial walks you through the steps of implementing a Video-on-Demand (VoD) content delivery application with Azure Media Services using REST APIs

trans-unit.source: Getting Started with Delivering Video on Demand (VoD) using REST APIs
trans-unit.target: Getting Started with Delivering Video on Demand (VoD) using REST APIs

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need an Azure account.
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need an Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <html></html>Azure Free Trial<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <html></html>Azure Free Trial<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: This quickstart walks you through the steps of implementing a Video-on-Demand (VoD) content delivery application using Azure Media Services (AMS) REST APIs.
trans-unit.target: This quickstart walks you through the steps of implementing a Video-on-Demand (VoD) content delivery application using Azure Media Services (AMS) REST APIs.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial introduces the basic Media Services workflow and the most common programming objects and tasks required for Media Services development.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial introduces the basic Media Services workflow and the most common programming objects and tasks required for Media Services development.

trans-unit.source: At the completion of the tutorial, you will be able to stream or progressively download a sample media file that you uploaded, encoded, and downloaded.
trans-unit.target: At the completion of the tutorial, you will be able to stream or progressively download a sample media file that you uploaded, encoded, and downloaded.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: The following prerequisites are required to start developing with Media Services with REST APIs.
trans-unit.target: The following prerequisites are required to start developing with Media Services with REST APIs.

trans-unit.source: Understanding of how to develop with Media Services REST API.
trans-unit.target: Understanding of how to develop with Media Services REST API.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>media-services-rest-overview</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>media-services-rest-overview</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: An application of your choice that can send HTTP requests and responses.
trans-unit.target: An application of your choice that can send HTTP requests and responses.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial uses <link><linkText>Fiddler</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial uses <link><linkText>Fiddler</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The following tasks are shown in this quickstart.
trans-unit.target: The following tasks are shown in this quickstart.

trans-unit.source: Create a Media Services account using Portal.
trans-unit.target: Create a Media Services account using Portal.

trans-unit.source: Connect to the Media Services account with REST API.
trans-unit.target: Connect to the Media Services account with REST API.

trans-unit.source: Create a new asset and upload a video file with REST API.
trans-unit.target: Create a new asset and upload a video file with REST API.

trans-unit.source: Configure streaming units with REST API.
trans-unit.target: Configure streaming units with REST API.

trans-unit.source: Encode the source file into a set of adaptive bitrate MP4 files with REST API.
trans-unit.target: Encode the source file into a set of adaptive bitrate MP4 files with REST API.

trans-unit.source: Publish the asset and get streaming and progressive download URLs with REST API.
trans-unit.target: Publish the asset and get streaming and progressive download URLs with REST API.

trans-unit.source: Play your content.
trans-unit.target: Play your content.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Create a Media Services account using Portal
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Create a Media Services account using Portal

trans-unit.source: In the Management Portal[], click New, click Media Service, and then click Quick Create.
trans-unit.target: In the Management Portal[], click New, click Media Service, and then click Quick Create.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Media Services Quick Create</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Media Services Quick Create</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In NAME, enter the name of the new account.
trans-unit.target: In NAME, enter the name of the new account.

trans-unit.source: A Media Services account name is all lower-case numbers or letters with no spaces, and is 3 - 24 characters in length.
trans-unit.target: A Media Services account name is all lower-case numbers or letters with no spaces, and is 3 - 24 characters in length.

trans-unit.source: In REGION, select the geographic region that will be used to store the metadata records for your Media Services account.
trans-unit.target: In REGION, select the geographic region that will be used to store the metadata records for your Media Services account.

trans-unit.source: Only the available Media Services regions appear in the dropdown.
trans-unit.target: Only the available Media Services regions appear in the dropdown.

trans-unit.source: In STORAGE ACCOUNT, select a storage account to provide blob storage of the media content from your Media Services account.
trans-unit.target: In STORAGE ACCOUNT, select a storage account to provide blob storage of the media content from your Media Services account.

trans-unit.source: You can select an existing storage account in the same geographic region as your Media Services account, or you can create a new storage account.
trans-unit.target: You can select an existing storage account in the same geographic region as your Media Services account, or you can create a new storage account.

trans-unit.source: A new storage account is created in the same region.
trans-unit.target: A new storage account is created in the same region.

trans-unit.source: If you created a new storage account, in NEW STORAGE ACCOUNT NAME, enter a name for the storage account.
trans-unit.target: If you created a new storage account, in NEW STORAGE ACCOUNT NAME, enter a name for the storage account.

trans-unit.source: The rules for storage account names are the same as for Media Services accounts.
trans-unit.target: The rules for storage account names are the same as for Media Services accounts.

trans-unit.source: Click Quick Create at the bottom of the form.
trans-unit.target: Click Quick Create at the bottom of the form.

trans-unit.source: You can monitor the status of the process in the message area at the bottom of the window.
trans-unit.target: You can monitor the status of the process in the message area at the bottom of the window.

trans-unit.source: Once account is successfully created, the status changes to Active.
trans-unit.target: Once account is successfully created, the status changes to Active.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the page, the MANAGE KEYS button appears.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the page, the MANAGE KEYS button appears.

trans-unit.source: When you click on this button, a dialog with the Media Services account name and the primary and secondary keys is displayed.
trans-unit.target: When you click on this button, a dialog with the Media Services account name and the primary and secondary keys is displayed.

trans-unit.source: You will need the account name and the primary key information to programmatically access the Media Services account.
trans-unit.target: You will need the account name and the primary key information to programmatically access the Media Services account.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Media Services Page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Media Services Page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When you double-click on the account name, the Quick Start page is displayed by default.
trans-unit.target: When you double-click on the account name, the Quick Start page is displayed by default.

trans-unit.source: This page enables you to do some management tasks that are also available on other pages of the portal.
trans-unit.target: This page enables you to do some management tasks that are also available on other pages of the portal.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can upload a video file from this page, or do it from the CONTENT page.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can upload a video file from this page, or do it from the CONTENT page.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Connect to the Media Services account with REST API
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Connect to the Media Services account with REST API

trans-unit.source: Two things are required when accessing Azure Media Services: an access token provided by Azure Access Control Services (ACS), and the URI of Media Services itself.
trans-unit.target: Two things are required when accessing Azure Media Services: an access token provided by Azure Access Control Services (ACS), and the URI of Media Services itself.

trans-unit.source: You can use any means you want when creating these requests as long as you specify the correct header values and pass in the access token correctly when calling into Media Services.
trans-unit.target: You can use any means you want when creating these requests as long as you specify the correct header values and pass in the access token correctly when calling into Media Services.

trans-unit.source: The following steps describe the most common workflow when using the Media Services REST API to connect to Media Services:
trans-unit.target: The following steps describe the most common workflow when using the Media Services REST API to connect to Media Services:

trans-unit.source: Getting an access token.
trans-unit.target: Getting an access token.

trans-unit.source: Connecting to the Media Services URI.
trans-unit.target: Connecting to the Media Services URI.

trans-unit.source: After successfully connecting to https://media.windows.net, you will receive a 301 redirect specifying another Media Services URI.
trans-unit.target: After successfully connecting to https://media.windows.net, you will receive a 301 redirect specifying another Media Services URI.

trans-unit.source: You must make subsequent calls to the new URI.
trans-unit.target: You must make subsequent calls to the new URI.

trans-unit.source: You may also receive a HTTP/1.1 200 response that contains the ODATA API metadata description.
trans-unit.target: You may also receive a HTTP/1.1 200 response that contains the ODATA API metadata description.

trans-unit.source: Posting your subsequent API calls to the new URL.
trans-unit.target: Posting your subsequent API calls to the new URL.

trans-unit.source: For example, if after trying to connect, you got the following:
trans-unit.target: For example, if after trying to connect, you got the following:

trans-unit.source: You should post your subsequent API calls to https://wamsbayclus001rest-hs.cloudapp.net/api/.
trans-unit.target: You should post your subsequent API calls to https://wamsbayclus001rest-hs.cloudapp.net/api/.

trans-unit.source: Getting an access token
trans-unit.target: Getting an access token

trans-unit.source: To access Media Services directly through the REST API, retrieve an access token from ACS and use it during every HTTP request you make into the service.
trans-unit.target: To access Media Services directly through the REST API, retrieve an access token from ACS and use it during every HTTP request you make into the service.

trans-unit.source: This token is similar to other tokens provided by ACS based on access claims provided in the header of an HTTP request and using the OAuth v2 protocol.
trans-unit.target: This token is similar to other tokens provided by ACS based on access claims provided in the header of an HTTP request and using the OAuth v2 protocol.

trans-unit.source: You do not need any other prerequisites before directly connecting to Media Services.
trans-unit.target: You do not need any other prerequisites before directly connecting to Media Services.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the HTTP request header and body used to retrieve a token.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the HTTP request header and body used to retrieve a token.

trans-unit.source: Header:
trans-unit.target: Header:

trans-unit.source: Body:
trans-unit.target: Body:

trans-unit.source: You need to proved the client_id and client_secret values in the body of this request; client_id and client_secret correspond to the AccountName and AccountKey values, respectively.
trans-unit.target: You need to proved the client_id and client_secret values in the body of this request; client_id and client_secret correspond to the AccountName and AccountKey values, respectively.

trans-unit.source: These values are provided to you by Media Services when you set up your account.
trans-unit.target: These values are provided to you by Media Services when you set up your account.

trans-unit.source: Note that the AccountKey for your Media Services account must be URL-encoded when using it as the client_secret value in your access token request.
trans-unit.target: Note that the AccountKey for your Media Services account must be URL-encoded when using it as the client_secret value in your access token request.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the HTTP response that contains the access token in the response body.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the HTTP response that contains the access token in the response body.

trans-unit.source: It is recommended to cache the "access_token " and "expires_in " values to an external storage.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended to cache the "access_token " and "expires_in " values to an external storage.

trans-unit.source: The token data could later be retrieved from the storage and re-used in your Media Services REST API calls.
trans-unit.target: The token data could later be retrieved from the storage and re-used in your Media Services REST API calls.

trans-unit.source: This is especially useful for scenarios where the token can be securely shared among multiple processes or computers.
trans-unit.target: This is especially useful for scenarios where the token can be securely shared among multiple processes or computers.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to monitor the "expires_in" value of the access token and update your REST API calls with new tokens as needed.
trans-unit.target: Make sure to monitor the "expires_in" value of the access token and update your REST API calls with new tokens as needed.

trans-unit.source: Connecting to the Media Services URI
trans-unit.target: Connecting to the Media Services URI

trans-unit.source: The root URI for Media Services is https://media.windows.net/.
trans-unit.target: The root URI for Media Services is https://media.windows.net/.

trans-unit.source: You should initially connect to this URI, and if you get a 301 redirect back in response, you should make subsequent calls to the new URI.
trans-unit.target: You should initially connect to this URI, and if you get a 301 redirect back in response, you should make subsequent calls to the new URI.

trans-unit.source: In addition, do not use any auto-redirect/follow logic in your requests.
trans-unit.target: In addition, do not use any auto-redirect/follow logic in your requests.

trans-unit.source: HTTP verbs and request bodies will not be forwarded to the new URI.
trans-unit.target: HTTP verbs and request bodies will not be forwarded to the new URI.

trans-unit.source: Note that the root URI for uploading and downloading Asset files is https://yourstorageaccount.blob.core.windows.net/ where the storage account name is the same one you used during your Media Services account setup.
trans-unit.target: Note that the root URI for uploading and downloading Asset files is https://yourstorageaccount.blob.core.windows.net/ where the storage account name is the same one you used during your Media Services account setup.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates HTTP request to the Media Services root URI (https://media.windows.net/).
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates HTTP request to the Media Services root URI (https://media.windows.net/).

trans-unit.source: The request gets a 301 redirect back in response.
trans-unit.target: The request gets a 301 redirect back in response.

trans-unit.source: The subsequent request is using the new URI (https://wamsbayclus001rest-hs.cloudapp.net/api/).
trans-unit.target: The subsequent request is using the new URI (https://wamsbayclus001rest-hs.cloudapp.net/api/).

trans-unit.source: HTTP Request:
trans-unit.target: HTTP Request:

trans-unit.source: HTTP Response:
trans-unit.target: HTTP Response:

trans-unit.source: HTTP Request (using the new URI):
trans-unit.target: HTTP Request (using the new URI):

trans-unit.source: HTTP Response:
trans-unit.target: HTTP Response:

trans-unit.source: From now on the new URI will be used in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: From now on the new URI will be used in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Create a new asset and upload a video file with REST API
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Create a new asset and upload a video file with REST API

trans-unit.source: In Media Services, you upload your digital files into an asset.
trans-unit.target: In Media Services, you upload your digital files into an asset.

trans-unit.source: The Asset entity can contain video, audio, images, thumbnail collections, text tracks and closed caption files (and the metadata about these files.)
trans-unit.target: The Asset entity can contain video, audio, images, thumbnail collections, text tracks and closed caption files (and the metadata about these files.)

trans-unit.source: Once the files are uploaded into the asset, your content is stored securely in the cloud for further processing and streaming.
trans-unit.target: Once the files are uploaded into the asset, your content is stored securely in the cloud for further processing and streaming.

trans-unit.source: One of the values that you have to provide when creating an asset is asset creation options.
trans-unit.target: One of the values that you have to provide when creating an asset is asset creation options.

trans-unit.source: The Options property is an enumeration value that describes the encryption options that an Asset can be created with.
trans-unit.target: The Options property is an enumeration value that describes the encryption options that an Asset can be created with.

trans-unit.source: A valid value is one of the values from the list below, not a combination of values from this list:
trans-unit.target: A valid value is one of the values from the list below, not a combination of values from this list:

trans-unit.source: None = 0 - No encryption is used.
trans-unit.target: None = 0 - No encryption is used.

trans-unit.source: Note that when using this option your content is not protected in transit or at rest in storage.
trans-unit.target: Note that when using this option your content is not protected in transit or at rest in storage.

trans-unit.source: If you plan to deliver an MP4 using progressive download, use this option.
trans-unit.target: If you plan to deliver an MP4 using progressive download, use this option.

trans-unit.source: StorageEncrypted = 1 - Encrypts your clear content locally using AES-256 bit encryption and then uploads it to Azure Storage where it is stored encrypted at rest.
trans-unit.target: StorageEncrypted = 1 - Encrypts your clear content locally using AES-256 bit encryption and then uploads it to Azure Storage where it is stored encrypted at rest.

trans-unit.source: Assets protected with Storage Encryption are automatically unencrypted and placed in an encrypted file system prior to encoding, and optionally re-encrypted prior to uploading back as a new output asset.
trans-unit.target: Assets protected with Storage Encryption are automatically unencrypted and placed in an encrypted file system prior to encoding, and optionally re-encrypted prior to uploading back as a new output asset.

trans-unit.source: The primary use case for Storage Encryption is when you want to secure your high quality input media files with strong encryption at rest on disk.
trans-unit.target: The primary use case for Storage Encryption is when you want to secure your high quality input media files with strong encryption at rest on disk.

trans-unit.source: CommonEncryptionProtected = 2 - Use this option if you are uploading content that has already been encrypted and protected with Common Encryption or PlayReady DRM (for example, Smooth Streaming protected with PlayReady DRM).
trans-unit.target: CommonEncryptionProtected = 2 - Use this option if you are uploading content that has already been encrypted and protected with Common Encryption or PlayReady DRM (for example, Smooth Streaming protected with PlayReady DRM).

trans-unit.source: EnvelopeEncryptionProtected = 4 – Use this option if you are uploading HLS encrypted with AES.
trans-unit.target: EnvelopeEncryptionProtected = 4 – Use this option if you are uploading HLS encrypted with AES.

trans-unit.source: Note that the files must have been encoded and encrypted by Transform Manager.
trans-unit.target: Note that the files must have been encoded and encrypted by Transform Manager.

trans-unit.source: Create an asset
trans-unit.target: Create an asset

trans-unit.source: An asset is a container for multiple types or sets of objects in Media Services, including video, audio, images, thumbnail collections, text tracks, and closed caption files.
trans-unit.target: An asset is a container for multiple types or sets of objects in Media Services, including video, audio, images, thumbnail collections, text tracks, and closed caption files.

trans-unit.source: In the REST API, creating an Asset requires sending POST request to Media Services and placing any property information about your asset in the request body.
trans-unit.target: In the REST API, creating an Asset requires sending POST request to Media Services and placing any property information about your asset in the request body.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to create an asset.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to create an asset.

trans-unit.source: HTTP Request
trans-unit.target: HTTP Request

trans-unit.source: HTTP Response
trans-unit.target: HTTP Response

trans-unit.source: If successful, the following is returned:
trans-unit.target: If successful, the following is returned:

trans-unit.source: Create an AssetFile
trans-unit.target: Create an AssetFile

trans-unit.source: The <link><linkText>AssetFile</linkText><title></title></link> entity represents a video or audio file that is stored in a blob container.
trans-unit.target: The <link><linkText>AssetFile</linkText><title></title></link> entity represents a video or audio file that is stored in a blob container.

trans-unit.source: An asset file is always associated with an asset, and an asset may contain one or many AssetFiles.
trans-unit.target: An asset file is always associated with an asset, and an asset may contain one or many AssetFiles.

trans-unit.source: The Media Services Encoder task fails if an asset file object is not associated with a digital file in a blob container.
trans-unit.target: The Media Services Encoder task fails if an asset file object is not associated with a digital file in a blob container.

trans-unit.source: After you upload your digital media file into a blob container, you will use the MERGE HTTP request to update the AssetFile with information about your media file (as shown later in the topic).
trans-unit.target: After you upload your digital media file into a blob container, you will use the MERGE HTTP request to update the AssetFile with information about your media file (as shown later in the topic).

trans-unit.source: HTTP Request
trans-unit.target: HTTP Request

trans-unit.source: HTTP Response
trans-unit.target: HTTP Response

trans-unit.source: Creating the AccessPolicy with write permission.
trans-unit.target: Creating the AccessPolicy with write permission.

trans-unit.source: Before uploading any files into blob storage, set the access policy rights for writing to an asset.
trans-unit.target: Before uploading any files into blob storage, set the access policy rights for writing to an asset.

trans-unit.source: To do that, POST an HTTP request to the AccessPolicies entity set.
trans-unit.target: To do that, POST an HTTP request to the AccessPolicies entity set.

trans-unit.source: Define a DurationInMinutes value upon creation or you will receive a 500 Internal Server error message back in response.
trans-unit.target: Define a DurationInMinutes value upon creation or you will receive a 500 Internal Server error message back in response.

trans-unit.source: For more information on AccessPolicies, see <link><linkText>AccessPolicy</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on AccessPolicies, see <link><linkText>AccessPolicy</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to create an AccessPolicy:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to create an AccessPolicy:

trans-unit.source: HTTP Request
trans-unit.target: HTTP Request

trans-unit.source: HTTP Request
trans-unit.target: HTTP Request

trans-unit.source: Get the Upload URL
trans-unit.target: Get the Upload URL

trans-unit.source: To receive the actual upload URL, create a SAS Locator.
trans-unit.target: To receive the actual upload URL, create a SAS Locator.

trans-unit.source: Locators define the start time and type of connection endpoint for clients that want to access Files in an Asset.
trans-unit.target: Locators define the start time and type of connection endpoint for clients that want to access Files in an Asset.

trans-unit.source: You can create multiple Locator entities for a given AccessPolicy and Asset pair to handle different client requests and needs.
trans-unit.target: You can create multiple Locator entities for a given AccessPolicy and Asset pair to handle different client requests and needs.

trans-unit.source: Each of these Locators use the StartTime value plus the DurationInMinutes value of the AccessPolicy to determine the length of time a URL can be used.
trans-unit.target: Each of these Locators use the StartTime value plus the DurationInMinutes value of the AccessPolicy to determine the length of time a URL can be used.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Locator</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Locator</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: A SAS URL has the following format:
trans-unit.target: A SAS URL has the following format:

trans-unit.source: Some considerations apply:
trans-unit.target: Some considerations apply:

trans-unit.source: You cannot have more than five unique Locators associated with a given Asset at one time.
trans-unit.target: You cannot have more than five unique Locators associated with a given Asset at one time.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Locator.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see Locator.

trans-unit.source: If you need to upload your files immediately, you should set your StartTime value to five minutes before the current time.
trans-unit.target: If you need to upload your files immediately, you should set your StartTime value to five minutes before the current time.

trans-unit.source: This is because there may be clock skew between your client machine and Media Services.
trans-unit.target: This is because there may be clock skew between your client machine and Media Services.

trans-unit.source: Also, your StartTime value must be in the following DateTime format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ (for example, "2014-05-23T17:53:50Z").
trans-unit.target: Also, your StartTime value must be in the following DateTime format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ (for example, "2014-05-23T17:53:50Z").

trans-unit.source: There may be a 30-40 second delay after a Locator is created to when it is available for use.
trans-unit.target: There may be a 30-40 second delay after a Locator is created to when it is available for use.

trans-unit.source: This issue applies to both SAS URL and Origin Locators.
trans-unit.target: This issue applies to both SAS URL and Origin Locators.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to create a SAS URL Locator, as defined by the Type property in the request body ("1" for a SAS locator and "2" for an On-Demand origin locator).
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to create a SAS URL Locator, as defined by the Type property in the request body ("1" for a SAS locator and "2" for an On-Demand origin locator).

trans-unit.source: The Path property returned contains the URL that you must use to upload your file.
trans-unit.target: The Path property returned contains the URL that you must use to upload your file.

trans-unit.source: HTTP Request
trans-unit.target: HTTP Request

trans-unit.source: HTTP Response
trans-unit.target: HTTP Response

trans-unit.source: If successful, the following response is returned:
trans-unit.target: If successful, the following response is returned:

trans-unit.source: Upload a file into a blob storage container
trans-unit.target: Upload a file into a blob storage container

trans-unit.source: Once you have the AccessPolicy and Locator set, the actual file is uploaded to an Azure Blob Storage container using the Azure Storage REST APIs.
trans-unit.target: Once you have the AccessPolicy and Locator set, the actual file is uploaded to an Azure Blob Storage container using the Azure Storage REST APIs.

trans-unit.source: You can either upload in page or block blobs.
trans-unit.target: You can either upload in page or block blobs.

trans-unit.source: You must add the file name for the file you want to upload to the Locator Path value received in the previous section.
trans-unit.target: You must add the file name for the file you want to upload to the Locator Path value received in the previous section.

trans-unit.source: For example, https://storagetestaccount001.blob.core.windows.net/asset-e7b02da4-5a69-40e7-a8db-e8f4f697aac0/BigBuckBunny.mp4?
trans-unit.target: For example, https://storagetestaccount001.blob.core.windows.net/asset-e7b02da4-5a69-40e7-a8db-e8f4f697aac0/BigBuckBunny.mp4?

trans-unit.source: For more information on working with Azure storage blobs, see <link><linkText>Blob Service REST API</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on working with Azure storage blobs, see <link><linkText>Blob Service REST API</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Update the AssetFile
trans-unit.target: Update the AssetFile

trans-unit.source: Now that you've uploaded your file, update the FileAsset size (and other) information.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've uploaded your file, update the FileAsset size (and other) information.

trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.target: HTTP Response

trans-unit.source: If successful, the following is returned:
trans-unit.target: If successful, the following is returned:

trans-unit.source: HTTP/1.1 204 No Content
trans-unit.target: HTTP/1.1 204 No Content

trans-unit.source: Delete the Locator and AccessPolicy

trans-unit.source: HTTP Request

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Configure streaming units with REST API
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Configure streaming units with REST API

trans-unit.source: When working with Azure Media Services one of the most common scenarios is delivering adaptive bitrate streaming to your clients.
trans-unit.target: When working with Azure Media Services one of the most common scenarios is delivering adaptive bitrate streaming to your clients.

trans-unit.source: With adaptive bitrate streaming, the client can switch to a higher or lower bitrate stream as the video is displayed based on the current network bandwidth, CPU utilization, and other factors.
trans-unit.target: With adaptive bitrate streaming, the client can switch to a higher or lower bitrate stream as the video is displayed based on the current network bandwidth, CPU utilization, and other factors.

trans-unit.source: Media Services supports the following adaptive bitrate streaming technologies: HTTP Live Streaming (HLS), Smooth Streaming, MPEG DASH, and HDS (for Adobe PrimeTime/Access licensees only).
trans-unit.target: Media Services supports the following adaptive bitrate streaming technologies: HTTP Live Streaming (HLS), Smooth Streaming, MPEG DASH, and HDS (for Adobe PrimeTime/Access licensees only).

trans-unit.source: Media Services provides dynamic packaging which allows you to deliver your adaptive bitrate MP4 or Smooth Streaming encoded content in streaming formats supported by Media Services (MPEG DASH, HLS, Smooth Streaming, HDS) without you having to re-package into these streaming formats.
trans-unit.target: Media Services provides dynamic packaging which allows you to deliver your adaptive bitrate MP4 or Smooth Streaming encoded content in streaming formats supported by Media Services (MPEG DASH, HLS, Smooth Streaming, HDS) without you having to re-package into these streaming formats.

trans-unit.source: To take advantage of dynamic packaging, you need to do the following:
trans-unit.target: To take advantage of dynamic packaging, you need to do the following:

trans-unit.source: get at least one streaming unit for the *streaming endpoint *from which you plan to deliver your content (described in this section).
trans-unit.target: get at least one streaming unit for the *streaming endpoint *from which you plan to deliver your content (described in this section).

trans-unit.source: encode or transcode your mezzanine (source) file into a set of adaptive bitrate MP4 files or adaptive bitrate Smooth Streaming files (the encoding steps are demonstrated later in this tutorial),
trans-unit.target: encode or transcode your mezzanine (source) file into a set of adaptive bitrate MP4 files or adaptive bitrate Smooth Streaming files (the encoding steps are demonstrated later in this tutorial),

trans-unit.source: With dynamic packaging you only need to store and pay for the files in single storage format and Media Services will build and serve the appropriate response based on requests from a client.
trans-unit.target: With dynamic packaging you only need to store and pay for the files in single storage format and Media Services will build and serve the appropriate response based on requests from a client.

trans-unit.source: For information about pricing details, see <link><linkText>Media Services Pricing Details</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about pricing details, see <link><linkText>Media Services Pricing Details</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To change the number of streaming reserved units, do the following:
trans-unit.target: To change the number of streaming reserved units, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Get the streaming endpoint you want to update
trans-unit.target: Get the streaming endpoint you want to update

trans-unit.source: For example, let's get the first streaming endpoint in your account (you can have up to 2 streaming endpoints in running state at the same time.)
trans-unit.target: For example, let's get the first streaming endpoint in your account (you can have up to 2 streaming endpoints in running state at the same time.)

trans-unit.target: HTTP Request:

trans-unit.target: If successful, the following is returned:

trans-unit.source: The allocation of any new units takes around 20 minutes to complete.
trans-unit.target: The allocation of any new units takes around 20 minutes to complete.

trans-unit.source: To check the status of the operation use the Operations method and specify the Id of the operation.
trans-unit.target: To check the status of the operation use the Operations method and specify the Id of the operation.

trans-unit.source: The operation Id was returned in the response to the Scale request.
trans-unit.target: The operation Id was returned in the response to the Scale request.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Encode the source file into a set of adaptive bitrate MP4 files
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Encode the source file into a set of adaptive bitrate MP4 files

trans-unit.source: After ingesting Assets into Media Services, media can be encoded, transmuxed, watermarked, and so on, before it is delivered to clients.
trans-unit.target: After ingesting Assets into Media Services, media can be encoded, transmuxed, watermarked, and so on, before it is delivered to clients.

trans-unit.source: These activities are scheduled and run against multiple background role instances to ensure high performance and availability.
trans-unit.target: These activities are scheduled and run against multiple background role instances to ensure high performance and availability.

trans-unit.source: These activities are called Jobs and each <link><linkText>Job</linkText><title></title></link> is comprised of atomic Tasks that do the actual work on the Asset file.
trans-unit.target: These activities are called Jobs and each <link><linkText>Job</linkText><title></title></link> is comprised of atomic Tasks that do the actual work on the Asset file.

trans-unit.source: As was mentioned earlier, when working with Azure Media Services one of the most common scenarios is delivering adaptive bitrate streaming to your clients.
trans-unit.target: As was mentioned earlier, when working with Azure Media Services one of the most common scenarios is delivering adaptive bitrate streaming to your clients.

trans-unit.source: Media Services can dynamically package a set of adaptive bitrate MP4 files into one of the following formats: HTTP Live Streaming (HLS), Smooth Streaming, MPEG DASH, and HDS (for Adobe PrimeTime/Access licensees only).
trans-unit.target: Media Services can dynamically package a set of adaptive bitrate MP4 files into one of the following formats: HTTP Live Streaming (HLS), Smooth Streaming, MPEG DASH, and HDS (for Adobe PrimeTime/Access licensees only).

trans-unit.source: To take advantage of dynamic packaging, you need to do the following:
trans-unit.target: To take advantage of dynamic packaging, you need to do the following:

trans-unit.source: encode or transcode your mezzanine (source) file into a set of adaptive bitrate MP4 files or adaptive bitrate Smooth Streaming files,
trans-unit.target: encode or transcode your mezzanine (source) file into a set of adaptive bitrate MP4 files or adaptive bitrate Smooth Streaming files,

trans-unit.source: get at least one streaming unit for the streaming endpoint from which you plan to deliver your content.
trans-unit.target: get at least one streaming unit for the streaming endpoint from which you plan to deliver your content.

trans-unit.source: The following section shows how to create a job that contains one encoding task.
trans-unit.target: The following section shows how to create a job that contains one encoding task.

trans-unit.source: The task specifies to transcode the mezzanine file into a set of adaptive bitrate MP4s using Azure Media Encoder.
trans-unit.target: The task specifies to transcode the mezzanine file into a set of adaptive bitrate MP4s using Azure Media Encoder.

trans-unit.source: The section also shows how to monitor the job processing progress.
trans-unit.target: The section also shows how to monitor the job processing progress.

trans-unit.source: When the job is complete you you would be able to create locators that are needed to get access to your assets.
trans-unit.target: When the job is complete you you would be able to create locators that are needed to get access to your assets.

trans-unit.source: Get a media processor
trans-unit.target: Get a media processor

trans-unit.source: In Media Services, a media processor is a component that handles a specific processing task, such as encoding, format conversion, encrypting, or decrypting media content.
trans-unit.target: In Media Services, a media processor is a component that handles a specific processing task, such as encoding, format conversion, encrypting, or decrypting media content.

trans-unit.source: For the encoding task shown in this tutorial we are going to use the Azure Media Encoder.
trans-unit.target: For the encoding task shown in this tutorial we are going to use the Azure Media Encoder.

trans-unit.source: The following code requests the encoder's id.
trans-unit.target: The following code requests the encoder's id.

trans-unit.source: HTTP Request
trans-unit.target: HTTP Request

trans-unit.source: HTTP Response
trans-unit.target: HTTP Response

trans-unit.source: Create a job
trans-unit.target: Create a job

trans-unit.source: Each Job can have one or more Tasks depending on the type of processing that you want to accomplish.
trans-unit.target: Each Job can have one or more Tasks depending on the type of processing that you want to accomplish.

trans-unit.source: Through the REST API, you can create Jobs and their related Tasks in one of two ways: Tasks can be defined inline through the Tasks navigation property on Job entities, or through OData batch processing.
trans-unit.target: Through the REST API, you can create Jobs and their related Tasks in one of two ways: Tasks can be defined inline through the Tasks navigation property on Job entities, or through OData batch processing.

trans-unit.source: The Media Services SDK uses batch processing; however, for the readability of the code examples in this topic, tasks are defined inline.
trans-unit.target: The Media Services SDK uses batch processing; however, for the readability of the code examples in this topic, tasks are defined inline.

trans-unit.source: For information on batch processing, see <link><linkText>Open Data Protocol (OData) Batch Processing</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information on batch processing, see <link><linkText>Open Data Protocol (OData) Batch Processing</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows you how to create and post a Job with one Task set to encode a video at a specific resolution and quality.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows you how to create and post a Job with one Task set to encode a video at a specific resolution and quality.

trans-unit.source: The following documentation section contains the list of all the <link><linkText>task presets</linkText><title></title></link> supported by the Azure Media Processor.
trans-unit.target: The following documentation section contains the list of all the <link><linkText>task presets</linkText><title></title></link> supported by the Azure Media Processor.

trans-unit.source: HTTP Request
trans-unit.target: HTTP Request

trans-unit.source: HTTP Response
trans-unit.target: HTTP Response

trans-unit.source: If successful, the following response is returned:
trans-unit.target: If successful, the following response is returned:

trans-unit.source: There are a few important things to note in any Job request:
trans-unit.target: There are a few important things to note in any Job request:

trans-unit.source: TaskBody properties MUST use literal XML to define the number of input, or output assets that will be used by the Task.
trans-unit.target: TaskBody properties MUST use literal XML to define the number of input, or output assets that will be used by the Task.

trans-unit.source: The Task topic contains the XML Schema Definition for the XML.
trans-unit.target: The Task topic contains the XML Schema Definition for the XML.

trans-unit.source: In the TaskBody definition, each inner value for <html></html> and <html></html> must be set as JobInputAsset(value) or JobOutputAsset(value).
trans-unit.target: In the TaskBody definition, each inner value for <html></html> and <html></html> must be set as JobInputAsset(value) or JobOutputAsset(value).

trans-unit.source: A task can have multiple output assets.
trans-unit.target: A task can have multiple output assets.

trans-unit.source: One JobOutputAsset(x) can only be used once as an output of a task in a job.
trans-unit.target: One JobOutputAsset(x) can only be used once as an output of a task in a job.

trans-unit.source: You can specify JobInputAsset or JobOutputAsset as an input asset of a task.
trans-unit.target: You can specify JobInputAsset or JobOutputAsset as an input asset of a task.

trans-unit.source: Tasks must not form a cycle.
trans-unit.target: Tasks must not form a cycle.

trans-unit.source: The value parameter that you pass to JobInputAsset or JobOutputAsset represents the index value for an Asset.
trans-unit.target: The value parameter that you pass to JobInputAsset or JobOutputAsset represents the index value for an Asset.

trans-unit.source: The actual Assets are defined in the InputMediaAssets and OutputMediaAssets navigation properties on the Job entity definition.
trans-unit.target: The actual Assets are defined in the InputMediaAssets and OutputMediaAssets navigation properties on the Job entity definition.

trans-unit.source: Because Media Services is built on OData v3, the individual assets in InputMediaAssets and OutputMediaAssets navigation property collections are referenced through a "__metadata : uri" name-value pair.
trans-unit.target: Because Media Services is built on OData v3, the individual assets in InputMediaAssets and OutputMediaAssets navigation property collections are referenced through a "__metadata : uri" name-value pair.

trans-unit.source: InputMediaAssets maps to one or more Assets you have created in Media Services.
trans-unit.target: InputMediaAssets maps to one or more Assets you have created in Media Services.

trans-unit.source: OutputMediaAssets are created by the system.
trans-unit.target: OutputMediaAssets are created by the system.

trans-unit.source: They do not reference an existing asset.
trans-unit.target: They do not reference an existing asset.

trans-unit.source: OutputMediaAssets can be named using the assetName attribute. If this attribute is not present, then the name of the OutputMediaAsset will be whatever the inner text value of the <html></html> element is with a suffix of either the Job Name value, or the Job Id value (in the case where the Name property isn't defined). For example, if you set a value for assetName to "Sample", then the OutputMediaAsset Name property would be set to "Sample". However, if you did not set a value for assetName, but did set the job name to "NewJob", then the OutputMediaAsset Name would be "JobOutputAsset(value)_NewJob".
trans-unit.target: OutputMediaAssets can be named using the assetName attribute. If this attribute is not present, then the name of the OutputMediaAsset will be whatever the inner text value of the <html></html> element is with a suffix of either the Job Name value, or the Job Id value (in the case where the Name property isn't defined). For example, if you set a value for assetName to "Sample", then the OutputMediaAsset Name property would be set to "Sample". However, if you did not set a value for assetName, but did set the job name to "NewJob", then the OutputMediaAsset Name would be "JobOutputAsset(value)_NewJob".

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to set the assetName attribute:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to set the assetName attribute:

trans-unit.source: To enable task chaining:
trans-unit.target: To enable task chaining:

trans-unit.source: A job must have at least 2 tasks
trans-unit.target: A job must have at least 2 tasks

trans-unit.source: There must be at least one task whose input is output of another task in the job.
trans-unit.target: There must be at least one task whose input is output of another task in the job.

trans-unit.source: For more information see, <link><linkText>Creating an Encoding Job with the Media Services REST API</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information see, <link><linkText>Creating an Encoding Job with the Media Services REST API</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Cancel a job
trans-unit.target: Cancel a job

trans-unit.source: Media Services allows you to cancel running jobs through the CancelJob function.
trans-unit.target: Media Services allows you to cancel running jobs through the CancelJob function.

trans-unit.source: This call will return a 400 error code if you try to cancel a Job when its state is canceled, canceling, error, or finished.
trans-unit.target: This call will return a 400 error code if you try to cancel a Job when its state is canceled, canceling, error, or finished.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to call CancelJob.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to call CancelJob.

trans-unit.source: HTTP Request
trans-unit.target: HTTP Request

trans-unit.source: If successful, a 204 response code is returned with no message body.
trans-unit.target: If successful, a 204 response code is returned with no message body.

trans-unit.source: You must URL-encode the job id (normally nb:jid:UUID: somevalue) when passing it in as a parameter to CancelJob.
trans-unit.target: You must URL-encode the job id (normally nb:jid:UUID: somevalue) when passing it in as a parameter to CancelJob.

trans-unit.target: Get the output asset

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Publish the asset and get streaming and progressive download URLs with REST API
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Publish the asset and get streaming and progressive download URLs with REST API

trans-unit.source: To stream or download an asset you first need to "publish" it by creating a locator.
trans-unit.target: To stream or download an asset you first need to "publish" it by creating a locator.

trans-unit.source: Locators provide access to files contained in the asset.
trans-unit.target: Locators provide access to files contained in the asset.

trans-unit.source: Media Services supports two types of locators: OnDemandOrigin locators, used to stream media (for example, MPEG DASH, HLS, or Smooth Streaming) and Access Signature (SAS) locators, used to download media files.
trans-unit.target: Media Services supports two types of locators: OnDemandOrigin locators, used to stream media (for example, MPEG DASH, HLS, or Smooth Streaming) and Access Signature (SAS) locators, used to download media files.

trans-unit.source: Once you create the locators, you can build the URLs that are used to stream or download your files.
trans-unit.target: Once you create the locators, you can build the URLs that are used to stream or download your files.

trans-unit.source: A streaming URL for Smooth Streaming has the following format:
trans-unit.target: A streaming URL for Smooth Streaming has the following format:

trans-unit.source: A streaming URL for HLS has the following format:
trans-unit.target: A streaming URL for HLS has the following format:

trans-unit.source: A streaming URL for MPEG DASH has the following format:
trans-unit.target: A streaming URL for MPEG DASH has the following format:

trans-unit.source: A SAS URL used to download files has the following format:
trans-unit.target: A SAS URL used to download files has the following format:

trans-unit.source: This sections shows how to perform the following tasks necessary to "publish" your assets.
trans-unit.target: This sections shows how to perform the following tasks necessary to "publish" your assets.

trans-unit.source: Creating the AccessPolicy with read permission
trans-unit.target: Creating the AccessPolicy with read permission

trans-unit.source: Creating a SAS URL for downloading content
trans-unit.target: Creating a SAS URL for downloading content

trans-unit.source: Creating an origin URL for streaming content
trans-unit.target: Creating an origin URL for streaming content

trans-unit.source: Creating the AccessPolicy with read permission
trans-unit.target: Creating the AccessPolicy with read permission

trans-unit.source: Before downloading or streaming any media content, first define an AccessPolicy with read permissions and create the appropriate Locator entity that specifies the type of delivery mechanism you want to enable for your clients.
trans-unit.target: Before downloading or streaming any media content, first define an AccessPolicy with read permissions and create the appropriate Locator entity that specifies the type of delivery mechanism you want to enable for your clients.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the properties available, see <link><linkText>AccessPolicy Entity Properties</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on the properties available, see <link><linkText>AccessPolicy Entity Properties</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to specify the AccessPolicy for read permissions for a given Asset.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to specify the AccessPolicy for read permissions for a given Asset.

trans-unit.source: If successful, a 201 success code is returned describing the AccessPolicy entity that you created.
trans-unit.target: If successful, a 201 success code is returned describing the AccessPolicy entity that you created.

trans-unit.source: You will then use the AccessPolicy Id along with the Asset Id of the asset that contains the file you want to deliver(such as an output asset) to create the Locator entity.
trans-unit.target: You will then use the AccessPolicy Id along with the Asset Id of the asset that contains the file you want to deliver(such as an output asset) to create the Locator entity.

trans-unit.source: This basic workflow is the same as uploading a file when ingesting an Asset (as was discussed earlier in this topic).
trans-unit.target: This basic workflow is the same as uploading a file when ingesting an Asset (as was discussed earlier in this topic).

trans-unit.source: Also, like uploading files, if you (or your clients) need to access your files immediately, set your StartTime value to five minutes before the current time.
trans-unit.target: Also, like uploading files, if you (or your clients) need to access your files immediately, set your StartTime value to five minutes before the current time.

trans-unit.source: This action is necessary because there may be clock skew between the client and Media Services.
trans-unit.target: This action is necessary because there may be clock skew between the client and Media Services.

trans-unit.source: The StartTime value must be in the following DateTime format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ (for example, "2014-05-23T17:53:50Z").
trans-unit.target: The StartTime value must be in the following DateTime format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ (for example, "2014-05-23T17:53:50Z").

trans-unit.source: Creating a SAS URL for downloading content
trans-unit.target: Creating a SAS URL for downloading content

trans-unit.source: The following code shows how to get a URL that can be used to download a media file created and uploaded previously.
trans-unit.target: The following code shows how to get a URL that can be used to download a media file created and uploaded previously.

trans-unit.source: The AccessPolicy has read permissions set and the Locator path refers to a SAS download URL.
trans-unit.target: The AccessPolicy has read permissions set and the Locator path refers to a SAS download URL.

trans-unit.source: If successful, the following response is returned:
trans-unit.target: If successful, the following response is returned:

trans-unit.source: The returned Path property contains the SAS URL.
trans-unit.target: The returned Path property contains the SAS URL.

trans-unit.source: If you download storage encrypted content, you must manually decrypt it before rendering it, or use the Storage Decryption MediaProcessor in a processing task to output processed files in the clear to an OutputAsset and then download from that Asset.
trans-unit.target: If you download storage encrypted content, you must manually decrypt it before rendering it, or use the Storage Decryption MediaProcessor in a processing task to output processed files in the clear to an OutputAsset and then download from that Asset.

trans-unit.source: For more information on processing, see Creating an Encoding Job with the Media Services REST API.
trans-unit.target: For more information on processing, see Creating an Encoding Job with the Media Services REST API.

trans-unit.source: Also, SAS URL Locators cannot be updated after they have been created.
trans-unit.target: Also, SAS URL Locators cannot be updated after they have been created.

trans-unit.source: For example, you cannot reuse the same Locator with an updated StartTime value.
trans-unit.target: For example, you cannot reuse the same Locator with an updated StartTime value.

trans-unit.source: This is because of the way SAS URLs are created.
trans-unit.target: This is because of the way SAS URLs are created.

trans-unit.source: If you want to access an asset for download after a Locator has expired, then you must create a new one with a new StartTime.
trans-unit.target: If you want to access an asset for download after a Locator has expired, then you must create a new one with a new StartTime.

trans-unit.source: Download files
trans-unit.target: Download files

trans-unit.source: Once you have the AccessPolicy and Locator set, you can download files using the Azure Storage REST APIs.
trans-unit.target: Once you have the AccessPolicy and Locator set, you can download files using the Azure Storage REST APIs.

trans-unit.source: You must add the file name for the file you want to download to the Locator Path value received in the previous section.
trans-unit.target: You must add the file name for the file you want to download to the Locator Path value received in the previous section.

trans-unit.source: For example, https://storagetestaccount001.blob.core.windows.net/asset-e7b02da4-5a69-40e7-a8db-e8f4f697aac0/BigBuckBunny.mp4?
trans-unit.target: For example, https://storagetestaccount001.blob.core.windows.net/asset-e7b02da4-5a69-40e7-a8db-e8f4f697aac0/BigBuckBunny.mp4?

trans-unit.source: For more information on working with Azure storage blobs, see <link><linkText>Blob Service REST API</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on working with Azure storage blobs, see <link><linkText>Blob Service REST API</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: As a result of the encoding job that you performed earlier (encoding into Adaptive MP4 set), you have multiple MP4 files that you can progressively download.
trans-unit.target: As a result of the encoding job that you performed earlier (encoding into Adaptive MP4 set), you have multiple MP4 files that you can progressively download.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.target: Creating an streaming URL for streaming content

trans-unit.source: The following code shows how to create a streaming URL Locator:
trans-unit.target: The following code shows how to create a streaming URL Locator:

trans-unit.source: If successful, the following response is returned:
trans-unit.target: If successful, the following response is returned:

trans-unit.source: To stream a Smooth Streaming origin URL in a streaming media player, you must append the Path property with the name of the Smooth Streaming manifest file, followed by "/manifest".
trans-unit.target: To stream a Smooth Streaming origin URL in a streaming media player, you must append the Path property with the name of the Smooth Streaming manifest file, followed by "/manifest".

trans-unit.source: To stream HLS, append (format=m3u8-aapl) after the "/manifest".
trans-unit.target: To stream HLS, append (format=m3u8-aapl) after the "/manifest".

trans-unit.source: To stream MPEG DASH, append (format=mpd-time-csf) after the "/manifest".
trans-unit.target: To stream MPEG DASH, append (format=mpd-time-csf) after the "/manifest".

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Play your content
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Play your content

trans-unit.source: To stream you video, use <link><linkText>Azure Media Services Player</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To stream you video, use <link><linkText>Azure Media Services Player</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To test progressive download, paste a URL into a browser (for example, IE, Chrome, Safari).
trans-unit.target: To test progressive download, paste a URL into a browser (for example, IE, Chrome, Safari).
